It's About More Than Just Math: Fear, Growth, and Adaptation

Math anxiety â a fear of getting math concepts and problems wrong and the resulting avoidance of math because of that â is something Iâve seen many times over my life and not just in children. Itâs just as prevalent in adults and, believe it or not, despite my PhD in math, I experienced math anxiety as a child, too. While some children allowed their math anxiety to grow into a lifelong avoidance of math, mine fueled my competitive spirit and led me to push ahead of my peers, learning advanced math concepts even when I wasnât able to get into the advanced math classes my middle school offered.

What Parents Need to Know About Math Curriculum in Algebra and Beyond

At the end of the day, algebra comes down to these three steps: define, recognize and produce. No matter if your child is in middle school or a PhD math program, itâs all about defining (can you understand it?), recognizing (can you identify it?), and producing (can you use it to produce results or new research?). If you can help your child with these three aspects of algebra at home, theyâll be better set up for success in the classroom and in the future.

Later Elementary Math Concepts and Strategies: What Parents Need to Know for Grades 3-6

Most students learn to multiply in school by memorizing their multiplication tables. Thereâs nothing wrong with memorizing multiplication tables, but a child must know what the multiplication tables mean. If theyâre multiplying seven by six, they need to have that picture in the back of their head of six groups of seven or seven groups of six. If not, they donât have a true understanding of what multiplication actually is and it wonât serve them later on in life. Take, for example, a child who knows that five times four is 20. She can solve the multiplication problem with ease.

How to Gamify Your Math Lessons

Making math fun for your child within the confines of your everyday world is easy. Letâs say youâre walking down the sidewalk with your child and they say, âOh, thereâs a train.â Thatâs an opportunity for you to ask how many train cars they can see. How many engines are on the train? Even if itâs just their toys sitting out on the floor, you could ask them, âCan you give me three toy dogs right now?â Then your child has to identify whatâs a dog, whatâs not a dog and how many of them equal three. Take whatever your child can identify and formulate a math lesson thatâs on their level.

Answers to Your Top Questions About Math Anxiety

Make no mistake. Math anxiety can and does affect the course of your life. The wife of a friend said to me, "I wanted to get a degree in physics, but it was all differential equations, so I became an English major." When she was a child, that's what she wanted to do; she wanted to be a physicist, but she gave that up because of math anxiety. The reality is, thereâs no such thing as a ânot a math person.â Whether itâs you or your child, those who arenât confident with mathematics are typically individuals who have math anxiety. Regardless of how much math anxiety exists in your household, remember: there is a solution.

Restoring the American Dream

We tell our children in the United States that they can grow up to be whatever they want. It is the quintessential American dream and why thousands if not millions of people want to move to our country. Find out why the dream is over before students even have a chance. It is all due to a gap between parent's understanding of what counting to 10 is versus what kindergarten means by counting to 10.
